title: Implement bulk operations support
description:
Unify single-issue and batch update operations under one command: `jit issue update`.

## Design Philosophy

Issue ID is just shorthand for a precise filter:
> `jit issue update <id>` â‰¡ `jit issue update --filter "id:<id>"`

## Command Interface

```bash
# Single issue mode (ID provided)
jit issue update <ID> [OPTIONS]

# Batch mode (filter provided)  
jit issue update --filter <QUERY> [OPTIONS]
```

**Mutual exclusivity:** ID and `--filter` cannot both be specified.

## Capabilities

### Single Issue Mode
- Update state, labels, assignee, priority
- Existing behavior, enhanced interface

### Batch Mode (New)
- Boolean query language (AND/OR/NOT operations)
- Filter by state, label, priority, assignee, blocked status
- Batch state transitions
- Batch label management (add/remove)
- Batch assignments
- Batch priority changes

## Safety Features

- Per-issue atomic file operations
- Auto dry-run for >10 matches
- Confirmation prompts for large operations
- Comprehensive error reporting (modified/skipped/errors)
- State transitions respect dependencies and gates
- Label operations respect hierarchy

## Example Usage

```bash
# Single issue
jit issue update 44104a30 --state done

# Batch: Complete milestone
jit issue update --filter "label:milestone:v0.9" --state done --yes

# Batch: Reassign work
jit issue update --filter "assignee:agent:old" --assignee agent:new

# Batch: Tag issues
jit issue update --filter "state:ready OR state:in_progress" --label milestone:v1.1
```

## Implementation Approach

Best-effort with per-issue atomicity:
- Each issue update is atomic (temp file + rename)
- Operations continue even if some issues fail
- Clear reporting of successes and failures
- Users can retry just the failures

This is essential for managing large workspaces efficiently, reducing overhead for both human users and AI agents when operating at scale.
